1.q_string:
The following reaction is used for the preparation of oxygen gas in the laboratory.

\(2 \mathrm{KClO}_3(\mathrm{~s}) \xrightarrow[\text { Catalyst }]{\text { Heat }} 2 \mathrm{KCl}(\mathrm{s})+3 \mathrm{O}_2(\mathrm{~g})\)

Which of the following statement is correct about the reaction?
The mass of \(\mathrm{H_2O_2}\) that is completely oxidised with \(30.2 \mathrm g\) of \(\mathrm{KMnO}_4\) (molar mass = 158 g mol–1) in acidic medium is:
In the reaction of formation of magnesium oxide magnesium undergoes:
In acidic medium, dichromate ion oxidizes ferrous ion to ferric ion. If the gram molecular weight of potassium dichromate is \(294 \mathrm{~g}\), is gram equivalent weight is \(\mathrm g\).

If equal volumes of \(1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{~KMnO}_4\) and \(1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{~K}_2 \mathrm{Cr}_2 \mathrm{O}_7\) solutions are used to oxidise \(\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}\) in acidic medium, then \(\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}\) will be oxidised:
What happens when a zinc rod is kept in a copper nitrate solution?

q_option: Oxidising agent is chlorine and reducing agent is sodium
Reducing agents is chlorine, oxygen and oxidising agents is sodium and sulphur
Oxidising agents is chlorine, oxygen and reducing agents is sodium and sulphur
Reducing agents is chlorine, oxygen and sulphur and oxidising agent is sodium
1.q_string:
The formation of sodium chloride involves two half reaction, which clearly show involvement of electrons.

 \(2 \mathrm{Na}(s) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{Na}^{+}(s)+2 \mathrm{e}^{-}\) 

\(\mathrm{Cl}_2(g)+2 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}(s)\)

Sum of the half reactions gives

\(2 \mathrm{Na}(s)+\mathrm{Cl}_2(g) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{NaCl}(s)\)

In terms of electron-transfer change, name the oxidising agent(s) and reducing agent(s).

q_option: The solution turns intense blue and silver is deposited on copper rod.
Silver deposits on the rod and Ag+(aq) is oxidised to Ag(s).
Copper deposits in the solution and Cu(aq) is reduced to Cu2+ (s)
Silver deposits in the solution and Ag+(aq) is reduced to Ag(s).

Bromine is a stronger oxidant than iodine

1.q_string:
Thiosulphate reacts differently with iodine and bromine in the reactions given below :

\(2 \mathrm{~S}_2 \mathrm{O}_3^{2-}+\mathrm{I}_2 \rightarrow \mathrm{S}_4 \mathrm{O}_6^{2-}+2 \mathrm{I}^{-}\)

\(\mathrm{S}_2 \mathrm{O}_3^{2-}+2 \mathrm{Br}_2+5 \mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O} \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{SO}_4^{2-}+2 \mathrm{Br}^{-}+10 \mathrm{H}^{+}\)

Which of the following statement(s) justifies the above dual behaviour of thiosulphate?

q_option: The oxidation number of hydrogen is always +1.
The algebraic sum of all the oxidation numbers in a compound is zero.
An element in the free or the uncombined state bears oxidation number zero.
In all its compounds, the oxidation number of fluorine is -1.
